chunks.text: Welcome to data structures and algorithms. These are fundamental concepts in computer science that help solve problems efficiently.
Arrays are the simplest data structure, storing elements in contiguous memory. They provide constant-time access by index.
Linked lists store elements in nodes, each pointing to the next. They're dynamic but have linear access time.
Stacks follow Last-In-First-Out principle. Common operations are push and pop. They're used in function calls and undo operations.
Queues follow First-In-First-Out principle. Enqueue adds elements, dequeue removes them. Used in task scheduling and BFS.
Hash tables provide near constant-time lookups using key-value pairs. They handle collisions through chaining or open addressing.
Trees are hierarchical structures with nodes and edges. Binary trees have at most two children per node.
Binary search trees maintain sorted order, enabling efficient searching, insertion, and deletion operations.
Heaps are complete binary trees with heap property. Min-heaps and max-heaps are used in priority queues.
Graphs represent relationships between entities. They can be directed or undirected, weighted or unweighted.
Sorting algorithms include bubble sort, selection sort, insertion sort, merge sort, quick sort, and heap sort.
Searching algorithms include linear search and binary search. Binary search requires sorted data but is much faster.
Dynamic programming solves complex problems by breaking them into simpler subproblems and storing results.
Time complexity measures algorithm efficiency. Big O notation describes worst-case scenarios.
Space complexity measures memory usage. Trade-offs between time and space are common in algorithm design.
Practice implementing these structures and algorithms to improve problem-solving skills and prepare for technical interviews.
